newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium urges regions to cut debt with CCB cash.
newsitem.headline: Belgium urges regions to cut debt with CCB cash.

text.p: Belgian Finance Minister Philippe Maystadt on Wednesday urged Belgium's towns and regions to cut their debt with the proceeds they will receive from the November bourse listing of publicly-owned bank Credit Communal/Gemeentekrediet (CCB).

"If the receipts from the listing were used to cover normal expenses this would pose enormous problems for the whole country in meeting the three percent (deficit) norm set in the Maastricht Treaty," Maystadt said in a statement.

CCB, Belgium's second largest bank, is due to list between 25 and 30 percent of its capital on the Brussels Stock Exchange this autumn as part of its cross-border alliance with French specialised lender Credit Local de France.
CCB has nominal capital of 15 billion Belgian francs but Belgian newspapers have estimated the bourse listing could raise up to 30 billion Belgian francs.

"The repayment of their debt would be the most sensible operation the municipalities could realise because they would reduce not only their level of indebtedness but also their interest charges," Maystadt said.
